review.title: Taste or Addiction?: Using Play Logs to Infer Song Selection Motivation
review.abstract: Online music services are increasing in popularity. They enable us to analyze people's music listening behavior based on play logs. Although it is known that people listen to music based on topic (e.g., rock or jazz), we assume that when a user is addicted to an artist, s/he chooses the artist's songs regardless of topic. Based on this assumption, in this paper, we propose a probabilistic model to analyze people's music listening behavior. Our main contributions are three-fold. First, to the best of our knowledge, this is the first study modeling music listening behavior by taking into account the influence of addiction to artists. Second, by using real-world datasets of play logs, we showed the effectiveness of our proposed model. Third, we carried out qualitative experiments and showed that taking addiction into account enables us to analyze music listening behavior from a new viewpoint in terms of how people listen to music according to the time of day, how an artist's songs are listened to by people, etc. We also discuss the possibility of applying the analysis results to applications such as artist similarity computation and song recommendation.

Although it is known that people listen to music based on themes (e.g. rock or jazz), we assume that if a user is dependent on an artist, he selects the artist's songs regardless of the topic. On this basis, we propose in this paper a probabilistic model for analyzing people's listening to music behavior. Our main contributions are threefold. Firstly, to the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to model music listening behavior taking into account the influence of dependence on artists. Secondly, by using real data sets of game protocols, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of our proposed model. Thirdly, we have conducted qualitative experiments and demonstrated that taking addiction into account enables us to analyze music listening behavior from a new viewpoint of how people listen to music according to the time of day, the songs an artist listens to, etc.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Given the amount of accessible music, it has become very popular for people to play music using such services, rather than physical media such as CDs. sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Analysis of Music Listening Behavior
sections.text: The analysis of people's music listening behavior has attracted a lot of attention because (1) people's music listening behavior is important from a social science perspective, and (2) the analysis results can provide useful insights into various applications such as music player interfaces and recommendation systems. People's music listening behavior has been analyzed from different angles. Rentfrow and Gosling [14] conducted an online survey and showed the correlations between music preferences and personality, self-assessment (e.g. wealthy and politically liberal), and cognitive skills (e.g. verbal skills and analytical skills). Renyolds et al. [15] conducted an online survey and reported that environmental metadata such as user activity, weather, and location influence a user's music choice. Berkers's analysis [3] using Last.fm game protocols showed significant differences between male and female music genre preferences of users.

sections.heading: 2.2 Application Based on Music Listening Logs
sections.text: Schedl and Hauger [17] combed Twitter4 for the hash tag # nowplaying and calculated the similarity of the artists using methods based on chance; their experimental results showed that listening logs could be used to derive similarity measures for artists; another application is playlist creation; Liu et al. [11] proposed a system for creating playlists that is informed by timestamps of a user's listening logs, in addition to music rating history and audio features such as waveforms; the most popular application is music recommendation; since personal music game logs are available, it has been popular to use session information to recommend songs. Park et al. [13] suggested session-based collaborative filtering (SSCF), which expands traditional collaborative filtering techniques by using preferred songs in the similar session. Slides and Fonseca [4] suggested session information to recommend songs, which consists of five song applications, including one for each session.

sections.heading: 3 Model
sections.text: As already mentioned, our model is based on the model of Zheleva et al. [18]. After summarizing the notations used in our model in Section 3.1, we first describe the model of Zheleva et al. [18] in Section 3.2 and then propose our model in Section 3.3.

sections.heading: 3.1 Notations
sections.text: Considering a music playback log record, U is a group of users in the record. Let lun = (u, a, do) denote the n-th game log of u-U. Specifically, user u plays a song by the artist a-A in due course. Here, A is the group of artists in the record. Without loss of generality, we assume that game logs are sorted in ascending order of their timestamps: do < do ′ for n < n ′. To capture the user's listening settings over time, we divide the user's game logs into sessions. Following Zheleva et al. [18] and Baur et al. [2] we use the time gap approach to generate sessions. If the gap between do and do + 1 is less than 30 minutes, lun and lun + 1 belong to the same session; if they belong to different sessions, let u = the 3rd session.

sections.heading: 3.2 Session Model
sections.text: The model proposed by Zheleva et al. [18], called the session model, is a probabilistic graphical model based on the latent dirichlet allocation (LDA) [1], which assumes that for each session there is a latent theme (e.g. rock or love song) that guides the selection of songs in the session. Figure 1 (a) shows the graphical model of the session model, in which shaded and unshaded circles represent observed or unobserved variables. In Figure K, the number of topics is mainly the number of minutes in the third session of u, θ the distribution of user topics and φ the distribution of topics artists. We assume that we have dirichlet priors of α or β. The generative process of the session model is as follows: - For each topic k {1, · ·, K} draws dirichu (β).

sections.heading: 3.3 Session with Addiction (SWA) Model
sections.text: Although Zheleva et al. [18] have demonstrated the usefulness of creating songs played on the basis of the theme of a session, we assume that users can select a song regardless of the theme. In such an addiction mode, we assume that the user directly selects a song without falling in love with a theme. In light of the above, our model accepts both theme and addiction-based song selections. Figure 1 (b) shows the graphical model of our proposed model. Each user has a Bernoulli distribution that controls the weight of influence for a session theme and addiction. To be more precise, when user u selects a song in a session, we assume that the choice is more likely to be influenced by the session theme.

sections.heading: 5 Quantitative Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we answer the following research question, based on our quantitative experimental results: Is the adoption of two factors that determine consumers "daily music tastes and dependence on artists effective in modelling music listening behavior?

sections.heading: 5.1 Dataset
sections.text: To verify the effectiveness of the proposed model, we constructed two sets of data: the first was created from music playback logs from a music download service in Japan; the second consisted of logs on Last.fm. To ensure repeatability, we used a publicly available music playback log on Last.fm provided by Schedl [16]. Similar to JPD, we extracted 10 weeks of log data between 1 / 1 / 2013 and 11 / 3 / 2013; we call the data set LFMD. From the 10 weeks of JPD data, we created two pairs of training and test data sets as follows. In the first / second set, the training data set LFD consists of logs from the first four / eight weeks and the test data sets WPD from the next two weeks.

sections.heading: 5.2 Settings
sections.text: In terms of hyperparameters, we use α = 1K and β = 50 | A | in the session model and in the session model with dependence (SWA) in accordance with other thematic modeling work. In addition, we use γ = 50 | A | and ρ = 0.5 in the SWA model. To compare the performance of the session model and the SWA model, we use the confusion of the two models. Perplexity is a widely used measure to compare the performance of statistical models [1], and the lower value represents the better performance. sections.heading: 5.3 Results
sections.text: Figure 2 shows the confusion for each dataset. In each dataset, regardless of the amount of training data and number of topics, the SWA model exceeds the session model. If we set the number of topics to more than 300, the session model could exceed the SWA model; but we set the maximum value of K to 300 for the following two reasons, the first being the hours spent on the learning process. For example, if the session model learns parameters for K = 300 using 8WJPD, it takes 9.8 times longer than the SWA model for K = 30 using 8WJPD (1713 minutes for the session model and 175 minutes for the SWA model). In data analysis, elapsed hours are an important factor; if it takes a long time to learn the parameters for a model, the model is unsuitable for data analysis. The second reason is the comprehensibility of the topics. If the number of topics becomes too large, it is difficult to understand the difference between the topics, the topic is useless for us.

sections.heading: 6 Qualitative Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we report on the qualitative analysis results in terms of user characteristics, performer characteristics and topic characteristics. Due to the space limitation, we show the results for the training data of 8WJPD only with K = 30. We not only analyze the music listening behavior of people, but also discuss how we can apply the analysis results.

sections.heading: 6.1 User Characteristics
sections.text: As we mentioned in Section 3.3, each user has a parameter that controls the degree of common taste in music and addiction when selecting songs. Considering a user u, we can get the ratio of these two factors from Equation (7), where addiction places the greatest emphasis on artists (ratio > 0.9) The result, where so many users are somewhere between these two extremes of behavior, further indicates the usefulness of taking addiction behavior into account in listening to music. By using the posterior distribution of latent variables in Equation (4) and (5), we can analyze the relationship between the degree of addiction and time.

sections.heading: 6.2 Artist Characteristics
sections.text: Just as in Section 6.1 given to an artist, we can add up p (x = 0) and p (x = 1) of all artist logs to determine the strength of common taste or addiction over time, and then normalize their sum to 1 to calculate the ratio of each factor of the artist. Figure 3 (b) shows a histogram based on the degree of addiction. It is noted that most artists have a high level of addiction, and from these results we can estimate whether the artist's songs are played repeatedly by users who are avid admirers of the artist, or by various users who listen to the artist's songs with songs by other artists. We also believe that the results could be used as one of the features to calculate the similarity between artists by assuming that similar artists have similar levels of addiction.

sections.heading: 6.3 Topic Characteristics
sections.text: Finally, we show that our model can also be used for theme analysis. In view of a theme k, we collected representative artists in the category. To be more precise, the top 20 artists in terms of φk were extracted. For each of the 20 artists, we collected all the logs in the training data and calculated the ratio of taste in music and addiction as described in Section 6.1. Then, we calculated the averages of each degree over 20 artists and normalized their total to 1. Figure 5 shows the ratio of 30 topics in which the topics are sorted in ascending order of addiction ratio. As you can see, the ratio between two factors differs greatly from topic to topic: the addiction ratio ranged from 0.297 (10th topic) to 0.620 (17th topic). As for the topics with low addiction, the 10th topic has the lowest value of 0.297. This topic is related to songs created by using VOCALOID [9], the popular song synthesizer theme software theme is the lowest in Japan, with 2892 songs being related to the lowest in Japan.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a probabilistic model for analyzing people's listening behavior that takes into account the user's usual musical taste and dependence on artists. Our experimental results based on real-world music game protocols showed that our model exceeded an existing model that only takes into account the user's taste for helplessness. In our qualitative experiments, we demonstrated the usefulness of our model in various aspects: time-dependent game protocol analysis (e.g. the level of addiction is high early in the morning and on weekdays), theme-based game protocol analysis (e.g. the level of addiction is low for an anime song theme), and so on. For future work, we are interested in applying the knowledge gained from the log analysis to applications such as calculating the similarity of artists and song recommendations, as in Section 6. We are also interested in extending our model by considering the temporal transition of addiction.
